input: Suppose you love math, and you had to choose just one proof to show someone to explain why it is that math is beautiful, something that can be appreciated by anyone from a wide range of backgrounds while still capturing the spirit of progress and cleverness in math.
translatedText: 假设你热爱数学，并且你必须选择一个证明来向别人解释为什么数学是美丽的，这是任何来自不同背景的人都可以欣赏的东西，同时仍然体现数学中的进步和聪明精神。

input: What would you choose?
translatedText: 你会选择什么？

input: After I put out a video on Feynman's Lost Lecture about why planets orbit in ellipses, published as a guest video over on MinutePhysics, someone on Reddit asked about why the definition of an ellipse given in that video, the classic two thumbtacks and a piece of string construction, is the same as the definition involving slicing a cone.
translatedText: 在我在《费曼失落的讲座》上发布了一段关于为什么行星绕椭圆轨道运行的视频（作为客座视频发布在 MinutePhysics 上）之后，Reddit 上有人问为什么该视频中给出了椭圆的定义，经典的两个图钉和一块弦结构，与切圆锥体的定义相同。

input: Well, my friend, you've asked about one of my all-time favorite proofs, a lovely bit of 3D geometry which, despite requiring almost no background, still captures the spirit of mathematical inventiveness.
translatedText: 好吧，我的朋友，你问了我一直以来最喜欢的证明之一，一个可爱的 3D 几何，尽管几乎不需要背景，但仍然抓住了数学创造力的精神。

input: For context and to make sure we're all on the same page, there are at least three main ways you could define an ellipse geometrically.
translatedText: 为了上下文并确保我们都在同一页面上，至少有三种主要方法可以定义椭圆的几何形状。

input: One is to say you take a circle and stretch it out in one dimension.
translatedText: 一种是说你取一个圆并将其在一维上拉伸。

input: For example, maybe you consider all of the points as xy coordinates, and you multiply just the x coordinate by some special factor for all the points.
translatedText: 例如，也许您将所有点视为 xy 坐标，然后将所有点的 x 坐标乘以某个特殊因子。

input: Another is the classic two thumbtacks and a piece of string construction, where you loop a string around two thumbtacks stuck into a piece of paper, pull it taut with a pencil, and trace around, keeping the string taut the whole time.
translatedText: 另一种是经典的两个图钉和一根绳子结构，您将一根绳子绕在粘在一张纸上的两个图钉上，用铅笔将其拉紧，然后四处描画，始终保持绳子拉紧。

input: What you're drawing by doing this is the set of all points so that the sum of the distances from each pencil point to the two thumbtack points stays constant.
translatedText: 通过这样做，您所绘制的是所有点的集合，以便每个铅笔点到两个图钉点的距离之和保持不变。

input: Those two thumbtack points are each called a focus of the ellipse, and what we're saying here is that this constant focal sum property can be used to define what an ellipse even is.
translatedText: 这两个图钉点分别称为椭圆的焦点，我们在这里所说的是，这个恒定焦和属性可以用来定义什么是椭圆。

input: And yet another way to define an ellipse is to slice a cone with a plane at an angle, an angle that's smaller than the slope of the cone itself.
translatedText: 定义椭圆的另一种方法是用平面以一定角度切割圆锥体，该角度小于圆锥体本身的斜率。

input: The curve of points where this plane and the cone intersect forms an ellipse, which is why you'll often hear ellipses referred to as a conic section.
translatedText: 该平面与圆锥相交的点的曲线形成椭圆，这就是为什么您经常听到椭圆被称为圆锥曲线的原因。

input: Of course, an ellipse is not just one curve, it's a family of curves, ranging from a perfect circle up to something that's infinitely stretched.
translatedText: 当然，椭圆不仅仅是一条曲线，它是一系列曲线，范围从完美的圆形到无限拉伸的曲线。

input: The specific shape of an ellipse is typically quantified with a number called its eccentricity, which I sometimes just read in my head as squishification.
translatedText: 椭圆的具体形状通常用一个称为偏心率的数字来量化，有时我只是在脑海中将其读作压扁。

input: A circle has eccentricity 0, and the more squished the ellipse is, the closer its eccentricity is to the number 1.
translatedText: 圆的偏心率为0，椭圆越被压扁，其偏心率就越接近数字1。

input: For example, Earth's orbit has an eccentricity 0.0167, very low squishification, meaning it's really close to just being a circle, while Halley's comet has an orbit with eccentricity 0.9671, very high squishification.
translatedText: 例如，地球轨道的偏心率为 0.0167，压缩程度非常低，这意味着它非常接近圆形，而哈雷彗星的轨道偏心率为 0.9671，压缩程度非常高。

input: In the thumbtack definition of an ellipse, based on the constant sum of the distances from each point to the two foci, this eccentricity is determined by how far apart the two thumbtacks are.
translatedText: 在椭圆的图钉定义中，基于每个点到两个焦点的距离的恒定总和，该偏心率由两个图钉之间的距离决定。

input: Specifically, it's the distance between the foci divided by the length of the longest axis of the ellipse.
translatedText: 具体来说，它是焦点之间的距离除以椭圆最长轴的长度。

input: For slicing a cone, the eccentricity is determined by the slope of the plane you used for the slicing.
translatedText: 对于切片圆锥体，偏心率由用于切片的平面的斜率确定。

input: And you might justifiably ask, especially if you're a certain reddit user, why on Earth should these three definitions have anything to do with each other?
translatedText: 你可能会合理地问，特别是如果你是某个 Reddit 用户，为什么这三个定义会相互关联？

input: I mean, sure, it kind of makes sense that each should produce some vaguely oval-looking stretched out loop, but why should the family of curves produced by these three totally different methods be precisely the same shapes?
translatedText: 我的意思是，当然，每种方法都应该产生一些看起来模糊的椭圆形拉伸环，这是有道理的，但是为什么这三种完全不同的方法产生的曲线族应该是完全相同的形状呢？

input: In particular, when I was younger I remember feeling really surprised that slicing a cone would produce such a symmetric shape.
translatedText: 特别是，当我年轻的时候，我记得对切割圆锥体会产生如此对称的形状感到非常惊讶。

input: You might think that the part of the intersection farther down would kind of bulge out and produce a more lopsided egg shape.
translatedText: 您可能会认为交叉点更下方的部分会凸出并产生更不平衡的蛋形。

input: But nope, the intersection curve is an ellipse, the same evidently symmetric curve you'd get by just stretching a circle or tracing around two thumbtacks.
translatedText: 但不是，相交曲线是一个椭圆，与拉伸一个圆或围绕两个图钉追踪所得到的明显对称曲线相同。

input: But of course, math is all about proofs, so how do you give an airtight demonstration that these three families of curves are actually the same?
translatedText: 但是，当然，数学就是证明，那么如何给出无懈可击的证明这三个曲线族实际上是相同的呢？

input: For example, let's focus our attention on just one of these equivalences, namely that slicing a cone will give us a curve that could also be drawn using the thumbtack construction.
translatedText: 例如，让我们将注意力集中在这些等价物中的一个上，即切割圆锥体将得到一条曲线，也可以使用图钉结构来绘制该曲线。

input: What you need to show here is that there exist two thumbtack points somewhere inside that slicing plane such that the sum of the distances from any point of the intersection curve to those two points remains constant, no matter where you are on that intersection curve.
translatedText: 这里需要显示的是，在该切片平面内的某处存在两个图钉点，使得从相交曲线的任何点到这两个点的距离之和保持恒定，无论您位于该相交曲线上的哪个位置。

input: I first saw the trick to showing why this is true in Paul Lockhart's magnificent book Measurement, which I would highly recommend to anyone young or old who needs a reminder of the fact that math is a form of art.
translatedText: 我第一次在保罗·洛克哈特（Paul Lockhart）的伟大著作《测量》中看到了解释为什么这是正确的技巧，我强烈推荐给任何需要提醒数学是一种艺术形式这一事实的年轻人或老年人。

input: The stroke of genius comes in the very first step, which is to introduce two spheres into this picture, one above the plane and one below it, each one of them sized just right so as to be tangent to the cone along a circle of points, and tangent to the plane at just a single point.
translatedText: 天才之举出现在第一步，就是在这幅画中引入两个球体，一个在平面上方，一个在平面下方，每个球体的大小都恰到好处，以便沿着点圆与圆锥体相切，并且仅在一点处与平面相切。

input: Why you would think to do this, of all things, is a tricky question to answer, and one that we'll turn back to.
translatedText: 为什么你会想到这样做，这是一个很难回答的问题，我们将回头讨论这个问题。

input: For right now, let's just say that you have a particularly playful mind that loves engaging with how different geometric objects all fit together.
translatedText: 现在，假设您有一个特别顽皮的头脑，喜欢研究不同的几何对象如何组合在一起。

input: But once these spheres are sitting here, I actually bet that you could prove the target result yourself.
translatedText: 但一旦这些球体坐在这里，我实际上打赌你可以自己证明目标结果。

input: Here, I'll help you step through it, but at any point if you feel inspired, please do pause and try to carry on without me.
translatedText: 在这里，我将帮助您逐步完成它，但在任何时候，如果您感到受到启发，请暂停并尝试在没有我的情况下继续进行。

input: First off, these spheres have introduced two special points inside the curve, the points where they're tangent to the plane.
translatedText: 首先，这些球体在曲线内引入了两个特殊点，即它们与平面相切的点。

input: So a reasonable guess might be that these two tangency points are the focus points.
translatedText: 因此，合理的猜测可能是这两个切点是焦点。

input: That means that you're going to want to draw lines from these foci to some point along the ellipse, and ultimately the goal is to understand what the sum of the distances of those two lines is, or at the very least to understand why that sum doesn't depend on where you are along the ellipse.
translatedText: 这意味着您需要从这些焦点到椭圆上的某个点画线，最终目标是了解这两条线的距离之和是多少，或者至少了解为什么会这样总和并不取决于您在椭圆上的位置。

input: Keep in mind, what makes these lines special is that each one does not simply touch one of the spheres, it's actually tangent to that sphere at the point where it touches.
translatedText: 请记住，这些线的特殊之处在于，每条线并不简单地接触其中一个球体，它实际上在接触点处与该球体相切。

input: And in general, for any math problem, you want to use the defining features of all the objects involved.
translatedText: 一般来说，对于任何数学问题，您都希望使用所有涉及对象的定义特征。

input: Another example here is what even defines the spheres.
translatedText: 这里的另一个例子甚至是定义球体的。

input: It's not just the fact that they're tangent to the plane, but that they're also tangent to the cone, each one at some circle of tangency points.
translatedText: 事实上，它们不仅与平面相切，而且还与圆锥体相切，每个都位于某个切点圆上。

input: So you're going to need to use those two circles of tangency points in some way.
translatedText: 因此，您需要以某种方式使用这两个切点圆。

input: But how exactly?
translatedText: 但具体如何呢？

input: One thing you might do is just draw a line straight from the top circle down to the bottom one along the cone.
translatedText: 您可以做的一件事就是沿着圆锥体从顶部圆圈一直画到底部圆圈。

input: And there's something about doing this that feels vaguely reminiscent of the constant sum thumbtack property, and hence promising.
translatedText: 这样做有点让人隐约想起常量总和图钉属性，因此很有前途。

input: You see, it passes through the ellipse, and so by snipping that line at the point where it crosses the ellipse, you can think of it as the sum of two line segments, each one hitting the same point on the ellipse.
translatedText: 您会看到，它穿过椭圆，因此通过在与椭圆相交的点处剪切该线，您可以将其视为两条线段的总和，每条线段都击中椭圆上的同一点。

input: And you can do this through various different points of the ellipse, depending on where you are around the cone, always getting two line segments with a constant sum, namely whatever the straight line distance from the top circle to the bottom circle is.
translatedText: 您可以通过椭圆的各个不同点来完成此操作，具体取决于您在圆锥体周围的位置，始终获得总和恒定的两条线段，即无论从顶部圆到底部圆的直线距离是多少。

input: So you see what I mean about it being vaguely analogous to the thumbtack property, in that every point of the ellipse gives us two distances whose sum is a constant.
translatedText: 所以你明白我的意思了，它与图钉属性有点相似，因为椭圆的每个点都给我们两个距离，其总和是一个常数。

input: Granted, these lengths are not to the focal points, they're to the big and the little circle, but maybe that leads you to making the following conjecture.
translatedText: 当然，这些长度不是焦点，而是大圆和小圆，但这也许会让你做出以下猜想。

input: The distance from a given point on this ellipse, this intersection curve, straight down to the big circle is, you conjecture, equal to the distance to the point where that big sphere is tangent to the plane, our first proposed focus point.
translatedText: 你猜想，从这个椭圆上的给定点（这条相交曲线）一直到大圆的距离，等于到那个大球体与平面相切的点（我们第一个提出的焦点）的距离。

input: Likewise, perhaps the distance from that point on the ellipse to the small circle is equal to the distance from that point to the second proposed focus point, where the small sphere touches the plane.
translatedText: 同样，也许从椭圆上的该点到小圆的距离等于从该点到小球体与平面接触的第二个建议焦点的距离。

input: So is that true?
translatedText: 那么这是真的吗？

input: Well, yes!
translatedText: 嗯，是！

input: Here, let's give a name to that point we have on the ellipse, q.
translatedText: 在这里，让我们为椭圆上的点命名 q。

input: The key is that the line from q to the first proposed focus is tangent to the big sphere, and the line from q straight down along the cone is also tangent to the big sphere.
translatedText: 关键是从 q 到第一个提出的焦点的线与大球体相切，并且从 q 沿着锥体垂直向下的线也与大球体相切。

input: Here, let's look at a different picture for some clarity.
translatedText: 为了清楚起见，让我们看一张不同的图片。

input: If you have multiple lines drawn from a common point to a sphere, all of which are tangent to that sphere, you can probably see, just from the symmetry of the setup, that all of these lines have to have the same length.
translatedText: 如果从一个公共点到一个球体绘制了多条线，所有这些线都与该球体相切，您可能可以从设置的对称性看出，所有这些线都必须具有相同的长度。

input: In fact, I encourage you to try proving this yourself, or to otherwise pause and ponder on the proof I've left on the screen.
translatedText: 事实上，我鼓励您尝试自己证明这一点，或者停下来思考我留在屏幕上的证据。

input: But, looking back at our cone slicing setup, your conjecture would be correct.
translatedText: 但是，回顾我们的圆锥切片设置，您的猜想是正确的。

input: The two lines extending from the point q on the ellipse tangent to the big sphere have the same length.
translatedText: 从椭圆上的点 q 延伸到大球体的切线的两条直线的长度相同。

input: Similarly, the line from q to the second proposed focus point is tangent to the little sphere, as is the line from q straight up along the cone, so those two also have the same length.
translatedText: 类似地，从 q 到第二个建议焦点的线与小球体相切，就像从 q 沿着圆锥体直线向上的线一样，因此这两条线也具有相同的长度。

input: And so, the sum of the distances from q to the two proposed focus points is the same as the straight line distance from the little circle down to the big circle along the cone, passing through q.
translatedText: 因此，从 q 到两个建议焦点的距离之和与从小圆沿锥体向下到大圆经过 q 的直线距离相同。

input: And clearly, that does not depend on which point of the ellipse you chose for q.
translatedText: 显然，这并不取决于您为 q 选择的椭圆的哪一点。

input: Bada-boom-bada-bang, slicing the cone is the same as the thumbtack construction, since the resulting curve has the constant focal sum property.
translatedText: Bada-boom-bada-bang，切割圆锥体与图钉结构相同，因为所得曲线具有恒定的焦和属性。

input: Now this proof was first found by Germenal, Germenal, Germenal, who cares, Dandelin, a guy named Dandelin in 1822, so these two spheres are sometimes called Dandelin spheres.
translatedText: 现在这个证明是由 Germenal，Germenal，Germenal，谁在乎，Dandelin，一个叫 Dandelin 的家伙在 1822 年首先发现的，所以这两个球体有时被称为 Dandelin 球体。

input: You can also use the same trick to show why slicing a cylinder at an angle will give you an ellipse, and if you're comfortable with the claim that projecting a shape from one plane onto another tilted plane has the effect of simply stretching out that shape, this also shows why the definition of an ellipse as a stretched circle is the same as the other two.
translatedText: 您还可以使用相同的技巧来说明为什么以一定角度切割圆柱体会得到椭圆形，并且如果您对以下说法感到满意，即将形状从一个平面投影到另一个倾斜平面上会产生简单地拉伸该形状的效果形状，这也说明了为什么椭圆作为拉伸圆的定义与其他两个相同。

input: More homework.
translatedText: 更多作业。

input: So why do I think this proof is such a good representative for math itself?
translatedText: 那么为什么我认为这个证明能够很好地代表数学本身呢？

input: That if you had to show just one thing to explain to a non-math enthusiast why you love the subject, why this would be a good candidate.
translatedText: 如果你只需展示一件事来向非数学爱好者解释为什么你喜欢这个学科，为什么这将是一个很好的候选人。

input: The obvious reason is that it's substantive and beautiful without requiring too much background, but more than that, it reflects a common feature of math that sometimes there is no single most fundamental way of defining something, that what matters more is showing equivalences.
translatedText: 显而易见的原因是，它既实质性又美观，不需要太多背景，但更重要的是，它反映了数学的一个共同特征，即有时没有单一的最基本的方法来定义某些事物，更重要的是显示等价性。

input: And even more than that, the proof itself involves one key moment of creative construction, adding the two spheres, while most of it leaves room for a nice systematic and principled approach.
translatedText: 更重要的是，证明本身涉及创造性构建的一个关键时刻，添加了两个领域，而其中大部分都为一种良好的系统性和原则性方法留下了空间。

input: And this kind of creative construction is, I think, one of the most thought-provoking aspects of mathematical discovery, and you might understandably ask where such an idea comes from.
translatedText: 我认为，这种创造性的构造是数学发现中最发人深省的方面之一，你可能会问这样的想法从何而来，这是可以理解的。

input: In fact, talking about this particular proof, here's what Paul Lockhart says in Measurement.
translatedText: 事实上，谈到这个特殊的证明，保罗·洛克哈特在《测量》中是这样说的。

input: I agree, but I think we can say at least a little something more about this.
translatedText: 我同意，但我认为我们至少可以对此多说一些。

input: While it is ingenious, we can perhaps decompose how someone who has immersed themselves in a number of other geometry problems might be particularly primed to think of adding these specific spheres.
translatedText: 虽然它很巧妙，但我们也许可以分解那些沉浸在许多其他几何问题中的人如何特别准备考虑添加这些特定的球体。

input: First, a common tactic in geometry is to relate one length to another, and in this problem, you know from the outset that being able to relate these two lengths to the foci to some other two lengths, especially ones that line up, would be a useful thing, even though at the start you don't even know where the focus points are.
translatedText: 首先，几何中的一种常见策略是将一个长度与另一个长度相关联，在这个问题中，您从一开始就知道能够将这两个长度与焦点与其他两个长度（尤其是对齐的长度）相关联这是一个有用的东西，即使一开始你甚至不知道焦点在哪里。

input: And even if it's not clear exactly how you'd do that, throwing spheres into the picture isn't all that crazy.
translatedText: 即使不清楚具体如何做到这一点，将球体扔进图片中也并不是那么疯狂。

input: Again, if you've built up a relationship with geometry through practice, you would be well acquainted with how relating one length to another happens all the time when the circles and spheres are in the picture, because it cuts straight to the defining feature of what it even means to be a circle or a sphere.
translatedText: 再说一次，如果你通过练习建立了与几何的关系，你就会很熟悉当圆和球体出现在图片中时，如何将一个长度与另一个长度相关联，因为它直接切入了几何的定义特征圆或球到底意味着什么。

input: This is obviously a specific example, but the point I want to make is that you can often view glimpses of ingeniousness not as inexplicable miracles, but as the residue of experience.
translatedText: 这显然是一个具体的例子，但我想说的一点是，你常常不会将巧妙的一瞥视为无法解释的奇迹，而是将其视为经验的残余。

input: And when you do, the idea of genius goes from being mesmerizing to instead being actively inspirational.
translatedText: 当你这样做时，天才的想法就会从令人着迷变成积极鼓舞人心。
